text: LOW CRAZY ANGLE. Where are we. All is SILENT save for a guttural, soft, scratchy, scatting. The CAMERA MOVES alon the floor, discovering a COCKROACH, moving quickly, darti in and out of pockets of light, and over clutter, scatter debris, discarded food wrappers, searching for something clearly not found. A REEL TO REEL tape machine spo out unheard music. 7-9-78 written on the label.

Duh - duh - da - dee - da - Da - dee - da - We PAN finding Miles framed like a never before seen icon photo of the cool; his ebony skin challenging the darknes his surroundings - he's a stunning sight. His chiseled features softened by shadow, his lithesome form draped in pale silks. In an instant, his spidery fingers run tender circles around the perimeters of his scatting lips, like memory of lost, but not forgotten love, then to a nearby of STAFF PAPER. Miles scrawls, jotting hieroglyphics, the encrypted language of the papers just seen blowing in the wind...

Da - dada - dee - dumdum - da - A DISTANT ANGLE. Dark. Steamy sunlight begs at the hems o drawn curtains. A former church. Little recollection of religion in the ghostly curves of the place. Now it feels haunted. Weeks, months of clothes strewn about, dirty dis empty Heineken and cognac bottles, magazines, newspapers grime carpet the floor, spiders perched in spiderwebs. Drips of errant flickering light from a TV OFF-SCREEN pla with the corners of the frame. On the silent screen, GRAI STOCK FOOTAGE of boxer JACK JOHNSON, July 4, 1910, the "F of the Century" against Great White Hope JAMES J. JEFFRIE before 20,000 people in Reno. In the 15th round Johnson knocks Jeffries down, and the nearly all white crowd jeer spitting rage...  We gather details of a lusciously frayed, once elegant tricked out pad of animal skins, Lucite and leather. PHOTOS on the wall shelves, on top of the piano, of Miles with everyone who's anyone, playing everywhere on the pla The world-beater. A sign says: "No Visitors"

Da - datdat - dedaw - dat - dat Miles sits riveted, eyes squeezed shut, 7-9-78 coming thr the headphones, as he scrawls on the pad, like a physicis trying to work out The Theory of Everything. STREET NOISES; car HORNS, shouting, other people’s shitty music, etc. A TEA KETTLE on the KITCHEN STOVE WHISTLING for all its worth... The PHONE RINGING and RINGING... INCESSANT KNOCKING ON THE FRONT DOOR... ON THE RADIO: Miles Davis, "So What" from "Kind of Blue". Miles sits in the midst of it all for a beat.

...fuck... Miles takes the headphones off, his concentration blown. stuffs them into the table DRAWER the reel to reel machin sits on. The drawer sticks and Miles battles with the bro thing, frustration ultimately winning, and leaves it half shut. This writing session is over. Miles' eyes adjust to the light, peek up, like flickering embers - stare at his TRUMPET on it's stand, shimmering b beneath the dust, like a glimmer of life, staring at him, challenging him to pick it up and play.

'Fuck you looking at? As to a wife in a marriage that has climbed downward from love, to war, to neglect. In an instant, and unresolved. Miles painfully stands and we almost hear the creeks of living. He squints hard as he turns to go into the kitche pivoting on his ruined hip. When Miles opens his eyes he FRANCES TAYLOR, early 30s, staring at him, perfection in chocolate, uncorrupted by the decay around her, with an a of where you want to be. She glides by locking him in her gaze, an enigmatic look on her face. Miles straightens up, locks into her eyes. He starts to s but Frances almost imperceptibly shakes her head, “no,” a walks on, HER LEGS, forever, and ever, as she turns and g up the staircase especially designed for this singular perfect view, and disappears into the BEDROOM, Gone from sight. Miles nods, picks up a half empty Heineken off the table tugs it back on the move, navigating through shadows thro by the cracks of light. Lays the empty beer bottle down o table with others. Passing, ignoring the RINGING PHONE... Passing, ignoring his own sounds on the RADIO Passing, ignoring the KNOCKING ON THE DOOR... Passing the TV - throwing a stiff right hook into the air unison with Jack Johnson, who knocks Jeffries down for a second time... INTO THE KITCHEN...stove on, pours green tea into a cup - sips, soothes his throat, lights a cigarette. After a lon drag Miles focuses in on the blue flame of the stove burn He’s captivated by the significance of the vision, if onl for himself. The FRONT DOOR KNOCKING STOPS and the cessation of this s snaps Miles out of it. He crosses back to the living room TAPPING ON THE WINDOW now, Miles ignores it; through a CR IN THE CURTAIN, we see the face of a pissed off Dave Braden... Finally, Miles has had it, and Miles picks up the RINGING
(into the phone) What?
(thick Kingston accent) Ah, you dere, huh, bumbaclot? You gonna make me hurt you, man.
Oh, is that right? (yells at the window) Get the fuck away from my window. Dave pops his head back out, leaving his post, disappears
Don’t play ‘round with your life, junkie. I fronted you product. You know what that means.
Fuck you, Mack. Get in line.
You show your junkie face in any my spots and - Miles hangs up. ON THE RADIO, "So What" ends - DJ PHIL SCHAAP comes on, rapping in the background:

Phil Schaap with you on KCWC-FM, New York, with the Miles Davis Marathon. That was the seminal "So What", from "Kind of Blue", 1959. That's the one in the time capsule, folks. The one they'll be talking about in a thousand years. The one you save from a burning building. The culmination. The mountaintop... Miles looks at the stereo SPEAKER, doesn't like what Scha saying. Miles pulls some reading glasses out of a little drawer filled with the things and grabs a YELLOW PAGES off the floor. He lights a cigarette, rips through the book until finds a number,. THE PHONE RINGS. Miles picks it up -

(on phone) Hello, is this Mi -  Miles hangs it up, picks it up again and dials. While it rings on the other end, Miles runs his finger over some cocaine residue on the table, and brushes his upper gums.
If you're out there listening, Miles, we miss you, the world misses you. Five years is just too long. Please, come back.
It's Miles Davis... Yeah, really. Put that motherfucker Schaap on the phone.

After Miles put his stamp on this new music, the modal form, he went on to -- (beat, stunned) Really? Oh, my goodness, this is incredible... Folks, I believe we have the Miles Davis on the line. (picks up the phone/on air) Mr. Davis, is this really you?
Yeah, it’s me.
My goodness. What an honor. This is-
You talk too damn much. A time capsule is for old shit, dead shit. And I missed on "Kind of Blue".
Missed? But Mr. Davis, I think most people would say it's a masterpiece. How exactly did you miss?
This ain’t a interview. I'm a tough guy and I know tougher guys. If you tape this, I'll kill you. You got that?  10
Yes sir, I got that.

Good. Now, forget it. (shift) And throw on some of that Sketches of Spain for me. Miles hangs up the phone. Sips more tea, fleetingly butts his cigarette in an overflowing ashtray, lights another o Dave Braden reappears, starts KNOCKING ON THE WINDOW agai Miles ignores him, goes to an EASEL with an in-process, w OIL PAINTING of a lush, mostly red and black, Picasso-esq woman in the stands of a bullfight, a dark-skinned matado stands in the ring. He stops, steps back, picks up the paint brush, dips it i color, adds a couple strokes to the work, studies it for few moments...

This one’s for you, Mr. Davis. Concierto De Aranjuez (Adagio), from Sketches of Spain... As "Concierto De Aranjuez (Adagio)", the romantic, epic m of battle...comes on the radio... A muffled conversation in front of his door pulls Miles' attention then - PHUMP -today's mail comes through the sl landing on a pile of weeks of unopened mail. Miles walks to the mail and with his bare foot sifts through today's arrivals. Dave starts knocking again, creaks open the mail slot.

Mr. Davis. If you could just open the door for a moment... Miles doesn't find what he's looking for. A storm cloud f around him. Miles walks over to the phone, dials. On the other end, George Butler's secretary answers:
George Butler's office.
It’s Miles.  11
Yes, sir. Hold a moment. A few moments later, HEAR GEORGE on the other end answer. He's solicitous, respectful. But this an old conversation
Hey, how are -
My money didn't come today.
Hello, Miles.
Where's my check? $20,000.
(careful but firm) Where is the session tape?
You trying to piss me off?
(sighs) Of course not, Miles, but we've been over this; we can't release more money —
Same shit -
- until Columbia gets that new music.
George-
I know there's gold on that tape, Miles. $20,000 is chump change compared to the business we’re going to do. Miles fumes silently.
Come on, man, let's do it. Let's put our heads together and really start working on that comeback.  12

I didn't go nowhere, George. Now you want some music, send me my money. Miles slams the phone down. Dave starts knocking again as “SKETCHES OF SPAIN" swells. Miles crosses tears open the with the chain on, his jaw seriously working his chewing Dave Braden stands there dressed differently than in the opening shoot out. No style: tweed, corduroy, loosened ti drops of red on his shirt, fresh scrape on his cheek, reddening around his eye. Dave's wearing some kind of sto that he's in the middle of.

Mr. Davis, hello. Really sorry to bother you but, I’m Dave Braden, Rolling Stone Magazine? Miles shuts the door - Dave sticks his foot in, preventin the door from closing. Miles' look - are you crazy?
Waitaminute...I'm here to do your comeback story. Wrong word. Miles expression changes. He nods.
Okay. The door closes. Dave straightens up, tucks in, slicks ba his hair, trying to appear half-way presentable. Miles flings the door open and - POW - clocks Dave in the face, Dave stumbles back -

What the - ? - recovers, fending Miles off. He blocks another punch - grabs hold of Miles shoving both of them into a crazy dos doe, and suddenly: Miles is OUTSIDE, barefoot, while Dave is INSIDE. Dave sl the door in Mile's face. INTERCUT: MILES OUTSIDE, DAVE INSIDE - Miles pounds on th door.
Open the door!  13
Take it easy!

Open it! Dave backs away from the door, takes the opportunity to w up the three steps, push open the saloon doors and peer i the room. ANGLE: PANS TO tape on the reel to reel, painting, boxing the TV, the ruinous decadent decay, evidence of empty coc bindles and residue; not what he was expecting. (on hush, quick) Inside the master’s disheveled lair, the rumors now reality, jazz's Howard Hughes reviled and revealed -
Open the goddamned door! Dave stows his works, comes back to the door.
Alright. No more punching, man. Dave opens the door and Miles charges in, his hip aching, coming at Dave -
Get the fuck outta my house. Hands up, Dave back-peddles, defensively away from Miles deeper into room...

Shit, hold it... I... It's a job -  14 Dave trips back over a table, falls to the ground - as Mi arrives over him, and Dave blurts it out like a safe word

Columbia.

Prick... The front door of the house opens - Miles peeks out ginge into the sun, then exits, now wearing a dope brocade robe silk scarf and sunglasses, looking around, paranoid -

Open the damn door. - as he hobbles down the stairs to the car - Dave reaches across the console and pops open the passenger door for Miles, who gets in. Clocks Dave’s running tape recorder o the dashboard.

Take that thing off my goddamned dash or I’m gonna slap you in the mouth with it.  15 Dave starts to comeback on Miles but bites his tongue, co out like something between a cough and a laugh. And Miles already scouring the car's interior for cocaine - glove compartment, map pocket, finding nothing but empty BINDLE which he crumbles up and tosses. Yeah, I know how to... I gotta do your homework for you?
Well, I could write some bullshit I got out of some...magazine. (MORE )

Miles Davis story. My words.

Ok. I was born... went to New York, met some cats, made some music, did some dope, made some more music... ...then you came to my house. Take a left.

That's it.

Hey -

Ok, guys -

Miles -
Can I say something -
